CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH is of great significance for achieving carbon neutrality. Here, we show a urea-assisted grinding strategy for synthesizing Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalysts (CZC-G) with optimized interfacial synergy, achieving superior performance in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The CZC-G catalyst demonstrated exceptional methanol selectivity (96.8%) and a space-time yield of 73.6 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1 under optimized conditions. Long-term stability tests confirmed no obvious deactivation over 100 h of continuous operation. Structural and mechanistic analyses revealed that the urea-assisted grinding method promotes the formation of Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce ternary interfaces and inhibits the reduction of ZnO, enabling synergistic interactions for efficient CO2 activation and selective stabilization of formate intermediates (HCOO*), which are critical for methanol synthesis. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra and X-ray absorption spectroscopy studies elucidated the reaction pathway dominated by the formate mechanism, while suppressing the reverse water-gas shift reaction. This work underscores the critical role of synthetic methodologies in engineering interfacial structures, offering a strategy for designing high-performance catalysts for sustainable CO2 resource utilization. Graphical Abstract Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interface prepared through a urea-assisted grinding strategy significantly enhances catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Cu-based catalyst Ternary interface Formate mechanism 1 Introduction The overexploitation and excessive consumption of fossil fuels have led to substantial emissions of greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide (CO2). These accumulating atmospheric concentrations intensify the greenhouse effect, resulting in a cascade of climate-related issues such as ocean acidification, glacial melting, and rising sea levels [1]. Among the different ways explored for controlling CO2 emissions, chemical conversion has attracted extensive attention. Converting the CO2 in the atmosphere into high-value-added chemicals and fuels through renewable energy can not only reduce atmospheric CO2 concentration but also alleviate renewable energy shortage [2,3]. Methanol (CH3OH), as the simplest saturated monoalcohol, has excellent characteristics such as high energy density and high octane number, and is known as hydrogen carrier for renewable energy [4–7]. In addition, as a basic organic matter, methanol is widely used in synthesizing a series of important industrial chemicals such as solvent and olefin [8]. With the depletion of nonrenewable energy source, methanol is also an alternative building block to produce gasoline. Therefore, in the past decades, researchers have worked on developing and studying catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, including Cu-based catalyst (Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, Cu/ZrO2) [9,10], In-based catalyst (In2O3/ZrO2) [11], oxide solid solution catalyst (ZnO/ZrO2, CdZrO x ) [12,13], and noble metal-based catalyst (Pd x Ga y , Pd/In2O3/ZrO2) [14–17]. Among the catalysts of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, Cu-based catalysts have always been the focus of research owning to their low cost and relatively high methanol yield. The industrial production of methanol is achieved by converting syngas over Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts [18]. However, the deactivation and low methanol selectivity of CO2 during the reaction process have hindered large-scale industrial applications. The methanol selectivity is reduced by the competing reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS, CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O), which also increases water production. The excess water leads to sintering of Cu nanoparticles and restructuring of interfaces with oxides like ZnO, thereby compromising the long-term stability of the catalyst [19,20]. To address the inherent limitations of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, researchers often introduce an additional metal (such as Zr, Ce, Ti, etc.) to replace Al2O3, thereby preparing multi-metal catalysts [21,22]. These catalysts exhibit synergistic effects and feature abundant interfaces, which enhance their overall performance. Among them, CeO2 is more basic and less hydrophilic than Al2O3, which is beneficial for activating CO2 and maintaining catalyst stability [23–26]. The influence of CeO2 addition to Cu-ZnO-based catalysts has been investigated as well. Hu et al. [24] demonstrated that the ternary CuZnCeOₓ catalyst significantly outperformed its binary counterparts (CuZnOₓ and CuCeOₓ) in terms of activity for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Zhu et al. [27] prepared a series of Cu-Zn-Ce oxide catalysts by flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) method and found that the methanol active sites were Cu sites with Zn-decorated. Meanwhile, cerium inhibited the occurrence of RWGS by accelerating the coverage of formate species on the Cu surface and the higher hydrogenation rate of CO intermediates. Ye et al. [28] developed a Ce-CuZn catalyst by incorporating Cu and Zn into the structure of a cerium-based metal-organic framework (Ce-MOF), thereby creating a catalyst with rich Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce sites. In the literature, diverse synthesis strategies including co-precipitation, FSP, and MOF pyrolysis have been explored for fabricating Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalysts with enhanced interfacial characteristics. While co-precipitation remains a conventional approach, it demonstrates limited capability in constructing catalysts with well-developed three-metal (Cu-Zn-Ce) interfacial architectures due to the divergent precipitation kinetics of constituent metallic species. Although more advanced techniques such as FSP and MOF pyrolysis can effectively engineer catalysts containing abundant ternary interfacial sites, their practical implementation is constrained by substantial technical barriers, including prohibitive energy consumption, sophisticated equipment requirements, and intricate process optimization challenges. These inherent limitations across different synthesis methodologies highlight the critical need for developing cost-effective and scalable fabrication approaches capable of precisely controlling multi-metal interfacial structures. In addition, prior investigations have generally encompassed multifaceted variations (e.g., divergent catalyst compositions, microstructural configurations, and formation of mixed oxides/alloys). However, there is still controversy over the mechanisms through which metal-oxide interfaces modulate the electronic configuration of surface Cu species and whether the efficient active sites of Cu-Zn-based catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol belong to a surface Zn-Cu alloy, defective Cu surfaces with Zn atoms, or Cu0-Zn2+ interfaces [29–34]. Here, we have developed a urea-assisted grinding method to synthesize Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalysts with enriched interfacial sites. Under identical elemental compositions, the optimized catalyst demonstrates exceptional methanol synthesis performance, achieving 96.8% methanol selectivity and a space-time yield (STY) of 73.6 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1 (10 wt% Cu loading, 3 MPa, 8000 mL·gcat –1·h–1). Furthermore, we identified and examined the active sites enriched with Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interfaces by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and explored the reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol via in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CZC-G-x catalyst was synthesized in two steps. Firstly, according to the molar ratio of Ce/Zn = 8 (Taking x = 8 as an example), weighed precursors of 0.297 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99%), 3.47 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99.5%) were mixed with 40.0 g urea (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99.5%), ground to uniform dispersion for 1 h, and then calcined in muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h to obtain the support [35]. Secondly, 10 wt% CZC-G-x was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation with the support. The 0.775 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Aladdin, ≥ 99%) was dissolved in 1 mL deionized water and added in a dropwise manner. The sample aged for 2 h in room temperature and dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight, and then the CZC-G-8 was obtained after calcined in muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h. The preparation method of CC-G was the same as above, except that it did not contain Zn. According to the ratio of Ce/Zn = 8 (molar ratio) and 10 wt% Cu, weighed precursors of 0.775 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99%), 0.297 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99%), 3.47 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99.5%) were dissolved in 100mL deionized water (Solution A), and the solution A was stirred vigorously for 1 h. In addition, moderate amount of Na2CO3 is dissolved in 100 mL deionized water to obtain the Solution B. Solution A and Solution B were pumped into 100 mL deionized water at the same speed in 80 °C water bath by peristaltic pump, and aged in 80 °C water bath for 2 h after dropping. Then the mixture was washed with deionized water until the pH = 7, and dried overnight in an 80 °C oven. CZC-CP was obtained after calcined in muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h. The CZC-IWI catalyst was synthesized in two steps. According to the molar ratio of Ce/Zn = 8, weighed precursors of 0.297 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99%) and 3.47 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥ 99.5%) were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water (Solution C). In addition, moderate amount of Na2CO3 is dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to obtain Solution D. Solution C and Solution D were pumped into 100 mL deionized water at the same speed in 80 °C water bath by peristaltic pump, and aged in 80 °C water bath for 2 h after dropping. Then the mixture was washed with deionized water until the pH = 7, and dried overnight in a 100 °C oven. The support was obtained after calcined in muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h. 10 wt% Cu was loaded on the support by incipient wetness impregnation. The weighed Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Aladdin, AR) was dissolved in 1 mL deionized water and added in a dropwise manner. The sample was aged for 2 h in room temperature and dried in a 100 °C oven overnight. CZC-IWI was obtained was obtained after calcined in muffle furnace at 400 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation and a nickel filter in the 2θ angle range from 5° to 90° (10°·min–1) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Inductively coupled plasma optic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed on an iCAP-7000 Plus series spectrometer (Thermo-Fisher). The test method was as follows: 10 mg of the sample was dissolved in a mixed solution overnight, then added to a 50 mL volumetric flask and diluted to the scale line. Four internal copper and cobalt concentration standard solutions were analyzed and used to create a standard curve (R 2 > 0.9999) before testing all samples. Nitrogen physisorption was carried out on an ASAP 2020 (Micrometrics) instrument at –196 °C after outgassing the samples for 6 h under a vacuum at 300 °C. TEM images were recorded by a FEI Talos F200S G2 at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. XPS spectra were obtained on an ESCAlab250xi electron spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) with monochromatic 150 Wal Kα radiation, and the reported binding energies were calibrated against the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), CO2- temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and CO-TPD experiments were tested on an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micrometrics) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In a typical H2-TPD experiment, the samples were pretreated in a helium stream at 300 °C for 120 min to remove moisture on the surface. 10% H2/He was passed into the reactor, with the temperature increasing at 10 °C·min−1 to 700 °C, and data were recorded every 0.5 min. The CO2-TPD profile was also recorded on the AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micrometrics). The samples were pretreated in a helium stream at 300 °C for 120 min to remove moisture on the surface. Then cooled down to room temperature and saturated by 10% CO2/Ar for 30 min. After purging the physically adsorbed CO2 on the surface with helium. The temperature was slowly increased to 700 °C and the detector recorded a signal at the same time. CO-TPD measurements were performed in the same way. In-situ DRIFTS were performed on a Nicolet Nexus iS-50 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector, recorded spectrum by 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm–1. The sample was first pretreated in 10% H2 flow at 200 °C for 2 h, followed by purging with Ar at 200 °C for 0.5 h, after which the background spectrum was collected. Then the sample was cooled to 25 °C and passed in CO2/H2/Ar (5/15/80) to 3 MPa. At last, the temperature was raised to 230 °C and the spectra were recorded with absorb time. DRIFTS-CO were performed on a Nicolet Nexus iS-50 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector, recorded spectrum by 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm–1. The sample was first pretreated in 10% H2 flow at 200 °C for 2 h. Then CO was introduced into the cell after cooling to room temperature and data were recorded for 90 min. The XAS experiments were performed at beamline BL20U of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) in fluorescence mode. The incident X-ray beam was tuned by a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator and then calibrated using a piece of Fe foil. The XAS data were processed and analyzed using the Demeter software package under the standard protocol. The coordination number, distance, and Debye-Waller factor were used as fitting variables. The WT EXAFS patterns were obtained using the HAMA Fortran package from ESRF. 2.3 Catalytic testing All the catalytic reactions were carried out in a high-pressure fixed-bed microreactor. Typically, 0.3 g of each catalyst (40–60 meshes) was mixed with 1.2 g of quartz sand (30–40 meshes), and then mixture was pretreated in 10% H2 flow at 200 °C for 2 h. Then the temperature was raised to 230 °C and the reactant gases (CO2/H2/Ar = 24/72/4, 3 MPa) were introduced into the reactor. The product gas was analyzed with an online gas chromatograph (GC, SHIMADZU) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a TCD. The performance of catalysts was evaluated by CO2 conversion, product selectivity, methanol yield and STY. The computational formula is as follows: (1) CO2 conversion, C CO2 (%) = (X CO2,in – X CO2,out)/X CO2,in × 100% (2) Products(i) selectivity, Sel(%) = (Ri × f i,m)/(∑ iRi × f i,m) × 100% (3) STYmethanol(gmethanol·kgcat −1·h−1) = F CO2,in × C CO2 × S methanol ×1000/W where X CO2,in and X CO2,out are the mole fractions of CO2 in feed gas and exit mixed gas, respectively; Ri is the area ratio of products in the chromatogram, fi,m is the correction for mass; F CO2,in (mol·h−1) is the molar flow rate of CO2 in feed gas. W(g) is the weight of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance A series of Cu-Zn-Ce catalysts were synthesized by urea-assisted grinding methods, co-precipitation method and incipient wetness impregnation method. The catalysts with different synthetic method were named CZC-G-x, CZC-CP-x and CZC-IWI-x (x-the molar ratio of Ce/Zn, default x = 8 without annotations). The actual Cu loading in various CZC catalysts was measured by ICP-OES (Table S2). The three catalyst preparation methods possessed comparable Cu loadings, with experimentally determined values consistently approximating 10 wt% in all cases. CZC-G, CZC-CP and CZC-IWI were pretreated under 10% H2 (1 bar) for 2 h before reaction. The catalytic performance of Cu-Zn-Ce (CZC) catalysts for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol was systematically evaluated under optimized reaction conditions (230 °C, 3 MPa) in a fixed-bed reactor with mixed feed gas (CO2:H2 = 1:3, 8000 mL·gcat –1·h–1). As shown in Fig. 1 and Table S1, the synthesis method significantly influenced catalyst performance. Notably, the CZC-G synthesized by urea-assisted grinding method displayed the highest methanol selectivity (96.8%) and space-time yield (73.6 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1) among Cu-Zn-Ce series sample (Figs. 1(a) and 1(b)). In contrast, CZC-CP and CZC-IWI, prepared by co-precipitation and incipient wetness impregnation methods, respectively, exhibited lower methanol selectivity and STY. The co-precipitation-derived CZC-CP catalyst showed a moderate STY of 38.4 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1, while the impregnation-prepared CZC-IWI demonstrated severely limited activity and almost no CO2 conversion. To systematically investigate the influence of Ce/Zn ratios on catalytic performance, a series of Cu-Zn-Ce catalysts with varying Ce/Zn ratios were synthesized while maintaining constant Cu loading and consistent preparation methodology. The catalysts were designated as CZ (Ce-free reference), CZC-G-6, CZC-G-8, CZC-G-10, and CC (Zn-free reference), corresponding to their respective Ce/Zn ratios. As shown in Figs. 1(c) and 1(d), the catalytic performance exhibited a distinct volcanic-shape on Ce/Zn ratio. The CZC-G-6 catalyst demonstrated substantially reduced CO2 conversion with a methanol STY of merely 41.6 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1. Simultaneously, the selectivity for the by-product CO is twice that of the main catalyst CZC-G-8. Although increasing the Ce/Zn ratio to 10 improved methanol STY to 60.8 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1, this value remained suboptimal compared to the peak performance of CZC-G-8. Notably, the complete Ce removal in the CZ catalyst and complete Zn removal in the CC catalyst resulted in drastic performance deterioration, with methanol STY decreasing to 8.7 and 22.5 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1, respectively. These results unequivocally demonstrate the critical importance of Ce/Zn ratio optimization in Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalyst systems. Both deficient and excessive Ce/Zn ratios significantly compromise methanol production efficiency while promoting undesired CO formation. This performance dependence likely originates from modifications in the active interfacial structure between metal components and oxide supports, emphasizing the necessity for balanced chemical composition in achieving optimal catalytic synergy. Moreover, compared to the performance of catalysts reported in literature for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the CZC-G catalyst exhibits higher methanol STY and lower reaction temperature per unit Cu content in Fig. 1(e). In addition, long-term stability assessments further confirmed the superiority of the CZC-G catalyst (Fig. 2 ). Under continuous reaction for 100 h at standard reaction conditions, both CO₂ conversion and methanol selectivity maintained stable performance without detectable deactivation. This result highlights the excellent stability of the Cu-Zn-Ce catalyst prepared by the urea-assisted grinding method. 3.2 Structure and chemical properties of catalysts TEM analysis was conducted to visualize the surface morphology and structural characteristics of the Cu-Zn-Ce species (Figs. 3(a) –(f)). The TEM analysis revealed that the CZC-G catalyst exhibits a well-defined lattice interlocking of Cu-Zn-Ce species. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the magnified TEM image of CZC-G displayed lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 2.9, 2.6, and 3.1 Å, which are consistent with the Cu2O (110), ZnO (011), and CeO2 (111), respectively [20,28,46]. In addition, as shown in the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping in Fig. 3(b), the Cu species (red dots), Zn species (green dots), and Ce species (pink dots) clearly overlap with high dispersion. This high-degree dispersion and interfacial contact among the constituent elements suggest strong synergistic interactions within the composite catalyst system. In contrast to CZC-G exhibiting ternary interfacial interactions, TEM characterization of CZC-CP and CZC-IWI catalysts reveals a predominant formation of bimetallic Cu-Ce interfaces (Figs. 3(c) and 3(e)), with notably fewer occurrences of the Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interfacial configurations. In addition, the EDS elemental mapping results revealed that CZC-CP and CZC-IWI did not exhibit a clearly overlap distribution of Cu species and Zn species on their surfaces, suggesting fewer ternary interfacial regions and potentially contributing to their inferior catalytic performance. Powder XRD of the catalysts was carried out to investigate crystalline structure of the fresh and used catalysts. In Figs. 4(a) , (b) and Figs. S1, S2, XRD patterns reveal clear diffraction peaks at 2θ of 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, and 56.3°, which are assigned to CeO2 (JCPDS 43-1002). The diffraction peaks located at 43.3° and 50.4° are attributed to Cu (JCPDS 04-0836), while those at 35.5° and 38.7° are attributed to CuO (JCPDS 48-1548) [47,48]. There were no diffraction peaks of ZnO in the XRD patterns, which may be due to the high dispersion of Zn species. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the diffraction peaks at 43.3° and 50.4° are obviously observed in CZC-G-U, CZC-CP-U, and CZC-IWI-U (U-used catalysts), which indicates that Cu in the catalysts is mainly in the metallic state after the reaction. In Fig. 4(a), the diffraction peaks at 35.5° and 38.7° are assigned to CuO in CZC-G-F, CZC-CP-F, and CZC-IWI-F (F-fresh catalysts). The above diffraction peaks also appear on fresh or used catalysts of CZC-G-6, CZC-G-8, and CZC-G-10 in Fig. S2. In addition, the relative intensity of the CeO2 diffraction peaks decreased with increasing Zn content in CZC-G-x-F. This change was likely due to Zn doping altering the crystal structure, thereby reducing the crystalline order and weakening the diffraction peak intensity. This indicates that the urea-assisted grinding method can effectively incorporate Zn species into CeO2. The specific grain size of Cu was calculated by Debye-Scherrer formula, which is shown in Table S2. By comparing the grain size of Cu synthesized by three different methods, it was found that CZC-G prepared by urea-assisted grinding method had the smallest grain size of Cu after reaction, while the Cu grain sizes of CZC-CP and CZC-IWI after reaction were 56.4 and 42.1 nm, respectively. The results reveal that the urea-assisted grinding approach significantly enhances dispersion efficiency and provides robust anchoring sites for Cu species, thereby improving material homogeneity. In addition, different Zn contents in CZC-G also have a significant impact on the dispersion of Cu species, and the dispersion results are consistent with the reaction performance results, indicating that an appropriate Ce/Zn ratio can better stabilize Cu species and enrich more Cu-Zn-Ce ternary active interfaces. The XRD patterns of Cu species exhibited no significant differences among CZC-G, CZC-CP, and CZC-IWI. Based on comprehensive analysis of catalytic performance, TEM characterization and XRD patterns, the Cu species in bulk phase do not play a decisive role in determining catalytic performance. Instead, the Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interface of catalyst surface is likely the key factor influencing catalytic activity. H2-TPR was executed to study the metal interaction and reducibility of catalysts in Fig. 4(c). The reduction peak of CZC-G at approximately 180 °C can be attributed to the reduction of dispersed Cu species, which weakly interact with the CeO2. In contrast, the peak at around 215 °C corresponds to the reduction of bulk Cu species, along with the concomitant reduction of Zn and Ce surface species [27,49]. It can be observed that the reduction peaks of CZC-CP and CZC-IWI are shifted to higher temperatures, specifically at 260 and 332 °C, respectively. This phenomenon can be attributed to the reduction of bulk Cu, which exhibits a strong interaction with CeO2, and the reduction of the Cu-CeO2 solid solution [50,51]. The difference of TPR results is essentially due to the difference in Cu-Zn-Ce interface, which is also consistent with the catalytic performance. The H2-TPR results show that catalysts prepared by different methods have different metal interactions. CO2-TPD was also performed to study the adsorption strength of catalysts for CO2. As depicted in Fig. 4(c), the low-temperature desorption peaks (50–200 °C) signify CO2 desorption occurring on weakly alkaline sites. In the temperature range of 200–400 °C, there are CO2 desorption peaks associated with moderately strong alkaline sites. The desorption peak above 450 °C is attributed to multidentate formate species formed at strongly alkaline sites [39]. By integrating the analysis of CO2-TPD with catalytic performance, it becomes evident that moderately strong alkaline sites are advantageous for the generation of the target product, methanol. In contrast, weak alkaline sites tend to produce more by-product CO. Moreover, strongly alkaline sites hinder the desorption of products, thereby reducing catalytic efficiency [17,52]. 3.3 Chemical state and coordination structure of active sites To further investigate the chemical states of active sites in the Cu-Zn-Ce catalysts, XPS was employed to analyze the surface composition and oxidation states of the spent catalysts. The XPS spectra (Fig. 5 and Figs. S4–S6) and corresponding quantitative analysis (Table S3) revealed distinct distributions of Cu, Zn, and Ce species across different valence states. As shown in the Cu 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 5(a)), the primary peaks at binding energies of 932.9 and 934.9 eV correspond to low-valence Cu species (Cu0/Cu+) and Cu2+, respectively [19,48,53]. Moreover, there is no satellite peaks near 942 eV, which are typically associated with Cu2+ species. These observations indicate that copper predominantly exists in its metallic (Cu0) and monovalent (Cu+) forms in the post- reaction catalysts, with minimal contribution from Cu2+ species. In addition, Zn 2p XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 5(d). The primary peaks at binding energies of 1022.1 and 1045.3 eV correspond to the Zn 2p 3/2 and Zn 2p 1/2, respectively. Notably, the distinct variations are observed in the Ce 3d XPS spectra and O 1s of CZC-G, CZC-CP, and CZC-IWI. The Ce 3d peaks are deconvoluted into four peaks of Ce3+ (u0, u‘ 0, u1, u‘ 1) and six peaks of Ce4+ (υ0, υ‘ 0, υ1, υ‘ 1, υ2, υ‘ 2) in Fig. 5(c). In addition, O 1s XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 5(f), which are deconvoluted into lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancies (OV), and hydroxyl oxygen (OOH) [54,55]. Quantitative analysis (Table S3) reveals that the catalysts prepared by three different methods are all rich in oxygen vacancies on their surfaces (OV/(OL+OV+OOH) > 50%), and the order of oxygen vacancies content is consistent with the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio, which is also consistent with the result of Raman spectra in Fig. S7. The oxygen vacancies of Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalysts generated by two ways, including I) the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and II) the replacement of Ce4+ by Cu or Zn species [28]. In Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalysts, oxygen vacancies are primarily attributed to Ce3+ reduced from Ce4+. The relatively fewer oxygen vacancies in CZC-G can be ascribed to its surface being rich in Cu-Zn-Ce interfaces, where Cu/Zn species block some of the oxygen vacancies [51]. The Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) was performed to further differentiate the valence states of Cu0/Cu1+ and Zn δ+/Zn2+ in Figs. 5(b) and 5(e). The content of Cu species and Zn species in different valence states are shown in Table S3. Compared with CZC-CP and CZC-IWI, Cu0 content of CZC-G on the surface of spent catalyst is as high as 42.1%. The Auger spectra of Zn species have displayed significant differences between CZC-G, CZC-CP, and CZC-IWI (Fig. 5(e) and Table S3). The content of Zn2+ reaches about 50% in CZC-G, while it is only 29.6% and 16.7% in CZC-CP and CZC-IWI, respectively. Compared with CZC-CP and CZC-IWI catalysts, CZC-G has a higher proportion of Cu0 and Zn2+ on its surface, and its methanol STY is the highest, which is consistent with the literature reporting that the active site of Cu-Zn system is Cu0-Zn2+. In addition, due to the rich Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interface in CZC-G, some oxygen vacancies are occupied by Cu and Zn species, resulting in a slight decrease in oxygen vacancy concentration. By comparing the CZC-G-6, CZC-G-8, and CZC-G-10 catalysts, it can be seen that as the Ce/Zn ratio increases, the Ce3+ ratio also increases, indicating that the Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interface does slightly inhibit the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, thereby reducing the oxygen vacancy concentration. However, the abundant Cu/Zn-OV-Ce sites on the CZC-G-8 ternary interface will increase the generation of Cu0 and Zn2+ species, thereby greatly increasing the yield of methanol. Furthermore, XPS was also performed on spent CZC-G-x catalysts to further study the effect of different Zn contents on active sites in Figs. S4–S6 and Table S3. According to the distribution of Cu species and Zn species in quantitative analysis, Cu0 shows a linear relationship with the increase of Zn content, while the content of Zn2+ gradually decreases with the increase of Zn content, which may be due to the influence of different surface Zn species dispersion. It is worth noting that the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio shows a decreasing trend with the increase of Zn content, indicating that there is a strong interaction between Zn species and Ce species at the interface, and excessive Zn species may occupy oxygen vacancies; On the other hand, combined with the volcanic-shape catalytic performance, it indicates that oxygen vacancies play an irreplaceable role in activating CO2 and improving CO2 conversion. Based on the valence state distribution of Cu species in the above analysis, it is speculated that Zn species transfer electrons to Cu species in CZC-G catalysts with abundant Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interfaces, resulting in more Cu0 and Zn2+ on the surface of CZC-G catalysts [30,46]. The DRIFTS-CO was further performed to investigate the surface interaction with CO as probe molecule. The peaks at ~2170 and ~2120 cm–1 are attributed to CO gas adsorption in Fig. S12. After 90 min of Ar purging, the CZC-IWI catalyst still exhibits a weak vibration peak at 2093 cm–1 in Fig. S12(f)., which is attributed to the linear-CO on Cu+. This result is also consistent with the fact that CZC-IWI contains the highest amount of Cu+ in the valence state distribution of XPS. Under Ar purging, the CO related vibration peak of CZC-CP quickly disappears, indicating its weak adsorption of CO, which is consistent with its higher CO selectivity of reaction performance. For CZC-G, the weak linear-CO vibration peak on Cu0 at ~2019 cm–1, which is probably due to the DRIFTS-CO was operated at room temperature and the CO adsorption on Cu0 species was weak. Compared with the CO vibration peak on Cu0 in the literature [28,56], this vibration peak is significantly shifted towards lower wavenumber, indicating that Cu is in an electron rich state, with electrons filling the antibonding π orbitals of CO, weakening the C-O bond and causing the vibration peak to shift towards lower wavenumber. Therefore, the DRIFTS-CO results also strongly demonstrate the electron transfer between Zn species and Cu species, resulting in Cu species being in an electron rich state. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra characterizations of the Cu K-edge were conducted to probe the coordination environment of Cu and Zn species in the spent CZC-G catalyst, with Cu foil, Zn foil and ZnO as references (Fig. 6 , Figs. S8, S9, and Tables S4, S5). As shown in Fig. 6(a), the XANES of Cu K-edge in CZC-G exhibited a slight shift to higher energy relative to Cu foil, indicating that Cu species on the spent CZC-G catalysts primarily maintained a metallic valence state. The valence state information displayed by XANES is consistent with the XPS results. To further investigate the detailed coordination of Cu in the spent CZC-G catalysts, Fourier-transformed k 2-weighted EXAFS in R space was employed, using Cu foil as the standard (Fig. 6(b)). The coordination number (CN) of Cu foil is 12 with direct distances of 2.54 ± 0.01 Å fitted with the Cu-Cu pathway [57]. The Cu species on CZC-G catalysts also showed a Cu-Cu fitting path with CN values of 5.82 ± 0.9 and distances of 2.54 ± 0.01 Å (Table S4). This indicates that the coordination environment of Cu species in CZC-G is in the metallic Cu-Cu state, and the lower CN suggests the presence of more unsaturated coordination, likely due to the high dispersion of Cu species and abundant Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interface. The XANES and EXAFS of Zn K-edge are presented in Figs. 6(c) and 6(d), with Zn foil and ZnO as standards. In Fig. 6(c), the white-line intensity of the Zn K-edge energy of CZC-G in the XANES curve is closer to that of ZnO, indicating that the valence of Zn species mainly exists in valence state of Zn2+. Fourier-transformed k 2-weighted EXAFS in R space was employed to further study coordination environment of Zn in spent CZC-G catalysts with Zn foil and ZnO as references (Fig. 6(d) and Table S5). Zn foil has Zn-Zn fitting path with coordination numbers of 6 and direct distance of 2.64 ± 0.01 Å (Table S5). ZnO includes Zn-O and Zn-O-Zn fitting paths with direct distance of 1.95 ± 0.02 and 3.25 ± 0.02 Å, respectively (Table S5). In Fig. 6(d), the Zn species on CZC-G catalysts have two fitting paths (Zn-O and Zn-O-Zn) with CN values of 1.24 ± 0.1 and 1.13 ± 0.6, and direct distances of 1.96 ± 0.01 and 3.25 ± 0.04 Å, respectively. Based on the results of XAS, the Zn species in CZC-G are mainly Zn2+, which may differ from the XPS results due to the fact that XAS obtains the coordination structure within the bulk phase, while XPS results provide the valence state information on the catalyst surface. XAS analysis of the CZC-G catalyst reveals distinct coordination environments for Cu and Zn species. The Cu species predominantly exist in metallic form (Cu0) with characteristic Cu-Cu coordination, while Zn adopts a Zn2+ oxidation state featuring Zn-O and Zn-O-Zn coordination motifs. Notably, the absence of detectable Cu-Zn coordination excludes the formation of Cu-Zn alloy phases, strongly suggesting that the catalytic active sites adopt a Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce configuration. This conclusion aligns coherently with the XPS results and catalytic performance trends. Compared to catalysts synthesized via conventional methods, the urea-assisted grinding approach employed for CZC-G enables the preferential formation of abundant Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce active centers with enhanced ternary interfacial sites. This structure promotes synergistic interactions among metallic Cu and Zn-Ov-Ce which leads to the superior CO2 conversion efficiency, higher methanol space-time yield (STY), and enhanced long-term stability of CZC-G. 3.4 Reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation on CZC catalysts To elucidate the relationship between surface intermediate species and the reaction mechanism, in-situ DRIFTS was performed under reaction conditions (CO2:H2 = 1:3, 3 MPa, 230 °C) in Fig. 7 and Fig. S10. The assignments of bond vibration peaks are provided in Table S6. As shown in Figs. 7(a) and 7(b), the vibration peaks located at 1610 and 1431 cm–1 on CZC-G, which are ascribed to ν as (HCO3) and ν s (HCO3) (asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations) of HCO3*. The stronger peaks at 2870, 2770, 2678, 1555, 1385, 1337 cm–1 of formate species (HCOO*) are attributed to δ (CH) (bending vibrations) + ν s (OCO), ν (CH), δ (CH) + ν as (OCO), ν as (OCO), δ (CH) and ν s (OCO). In addition, the weak vibration peaks are observed at 1047, 1087, 2865, and 2940 cm–1 of CH3O*, which could be assigned to ν (CO)-terminal, ν (CO)-bridge, ν s (CH3) and ν as (CH3), respectively. No vibration peak of *COOH (1765 and 1287 cm–1) is found on CZC-G, indicating that CO2 hydrogenation to methanol follow the formate (HCOO*) mechanism [5,58]. As the reaction proceeds, the vibration peaks of HCO3* and HCOO* species in CZC-G catalyst initially increase and then gradually stabilize, suggesting that CO2 and H2 are effectively hydrogenated into HCO3* species, which are further hydrogenated to generate HCOO* species. Subsequently, HCOO* species will continue to be consumed during hydrogenation, while the vibration peak of CH3O* species remains weak throughout the reaction period, indicating that CH3O* species are easily hydrogenated to generate CH3OH* and then rapidly desorb [59,60]. In-situ DRIFTS spectra of CZC-CP are presented in Figs. 7(c) and 7(d). Compared with CZC-G, it is evident that the vibration peaks of all intermediate species on the CZC-CP catalyst are significantly reduced. This indicates that the intermediate concentration on the surface of CZC-CP is relatively low, likely due to the lack of efficient active sites Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce. Moreover, although the vibration peak positions are similar to those of CZC-G, the relative intensities of the peaks for different intermediates vary considerably. As the reaction proceeds, the vibration peaks of HCO3* species increase significantly, while the vibration peaks of HCOO* species only slightly increase. The intensity of the HCO3* peak is much greater than that of HCOO*, indicating that the catalyst can effectively activate CO2 and H2 to generate HCO3* intermediates. However, the efficiency of continuing hydrogenation to generate HCOO* intermediates is low, which limits the rate of further hydrogenation to produce methanol. A similar situation is observed on the CZC-IWI catalyst. The lower vibration peaks of HCOO* species indicate that there are fewer HCOO* species on CZC-IWI. In addition, the relative intensity of the vibration peaks of CH3O* intermediate on CZC-IWI catalyst is much higher than that of CZC-G and CZC-CP, indicating that the adsorption state of CH3O* species on CZC-IWI is relatively stable, which inhibits its continued hydrogenation to generate CH3OH* and subsequently desorb to produce the target product methanol [5,8,34,48]. The above intensity-time shift spectra supplied the dynamic behaviour of intermediates converting on CZC-G, CZC-CP, and CZC-IWI. In-situ DRIFTS show the characteristic vibration peaks of intermediate species such as HCOO* and CH3O*, and no vibration peaks of *COOH species are found, which strongly proves that the reaction pathway of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol follows the HCOO* pathway in this work (Fig. S11). Additionally, the ratio of HCOO* and CH3O* increased over both CZC-G, CZC-CP, and CZC-IWI with in-situ DRIFTS testing, suggesting that the converting process of HCOO* to CH3O* was the rate-limiting step compared to the HCOO*-generating process during CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. As shown in Fig. S10, the HCOO*/CH3O* species ratio gradually increased in CZC-G during in-situ DRIFTS testing, while CZC-CP and CZC-IWI, due to their lower rates of CO2 to HCOO* species and CH3O* species conversion to methanol, respectively, resulted in a decrease in the HCOO*/CH3O* ratio, which is consistent with their catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrates that constructing Cu-Zn-Ce ternary interfaces through a urea-assisted grinding strategy significantly enhances catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The optimized CZC-G catalyst exhibits exceptional methanol selectivity and 100 h continuous operation without obvious deactivation. The unique synergy among Cu0, Zn2+, and Ce3+ (Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce) at ternary interfaces enables efficient CO2 activation and selective stabilization of formate intermediates (HCOO*), a critical step for methanol synthesis. This interface-driven mechanism suppresses CO formation by redirecting reaction pathways away from the reverse water-gas shift route. Comparative analysis with binary systems confirms that ternary synergy is indispensable for achieving both high activity and selectivity. The work elucidates how synthetic methodologies critically govern interfacial structures and catalytic functionality in multicomponent systems, offering a design principle for engineering metal oxide interfaces in energy conversion catalysts. These findings advance the rational development of high-efficiency catalysts for sustainable CO2 valorization and carbon-neutral fuel production. coredata.dc:description: CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH is of great significance for achieving carbon neutrality. Here, we show a urea-assisted grinding strategy for synthesizing Cu-Zn-Ce ternary catalysts (CZC-G) with optimized interfacial synergy, achieving superior performance in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The CZC-G catalyst demonstrated exceptional methanol selectivity (96.8%) and a space-time yield of 73.6 gMeOH·kgcat –1·h–1 under optimized conditions. Long-term stability tests confirmed no obvious deactivation over 100 h of continuous operation. Structural and mechanistic analyses revealed that the urea-assisted grinding method promotes the formation of Cu/Zn-Ov-Ce ternary interfaces and inhibits the reduction of ZnO, enabling synergistic interactions for efficient CO2 activation and selective stabilization of formate intermediates (HCOO*), which are critical for methanol synthesis. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra and X-ray absorption spectroscopy studies elucidated the reaction pathway dominated by the formate mechanism, while suppressing the reverse water-gas shift reaction. This work underscores the critical role of synthetic methodologies in engineering interfacial structures, offering a strategy for designing high-performance catalysts for sustainable CO2 resource utilization.
